Climate finance mechanisms refer to the various financial instruments and mechanisms that are used to mobilize and allocate funds for climate change mitigation and adaptation projects.

Systems that combine multiple energy storage technologies to optimize energy storage and release.

Biochar is a type of charcoal produced from biomass that is used as a soil amendment.
Biomass refers to organic matter, such as plants or plant-based materials, that can be used as a renewable energy source.
Biodigestion is the process of breaking down organic materials, such as food waste or agricultural residues, to produce biogas.
Biofuels are fuels produced from biomass, such as ethanol or biodiesel, that can be used as alternatives to fossil fuels.
Energy demand from urbanization refers to the increasing energy needs of urban areas due to population growth and urban development.
Cogeneration, also known as combined heat and power (CHP), is the simultaneous production of electricity and useful heat from the same energy source.
Electrolysis is a chemical process that uses an electric current to drive a non-spontaneous chemical reaction, such as the splitting of water into hydrogen and oxygen.
Foundational energy infrastructure refers to the essential physical structures and systems that support the production, distribution, and consumption of energy.
Enhanced energy recovery refers to technologies or processes that increase the efficiency of energy recovery from waste or other sources.
Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is a technology that captures carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from sources such as power plants and stores it underground to prevent it from entering the atmosphere.
Tags: Climate Change; Emissions Reduction; Carbon Sequestration

Description: Gas hydrates are ice-like crystalline structures that form when natural gas combines with water under specific temperature and pressure conditions.
Gasification is a process that converts carbon-based materials, such as coal or biomass, into synthesis gas (syngas) which can be used for power generation or as a chemical feedstock.
A gas turbine is a type of internal combustion engine that converts the energy from the combustion of a fuel, such as natural gas or liquid fuels, into mechanical energy.
Heating and cooling systems are technologies used to control the temperature and humidity of indoor spaces for comfort and energy efficiency.
Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is natural gas that has been cooled to a liquid state for easier storage and transportation.
Tidal power is a form of hydropower that converts the energy from the tides into electricity.
Tags: Renewable Energy; Tidal Energy; Ocean Power

Description: Battery recycling is the process of reusing or extracting valuable materials from used batteries to reduce waste and environmental impact.

Description: Integrated resource planning is a process that helps utilities and energy providers make informed decisions about the mix of energy resources and technologies to meet future energy demand.
